descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: American Political Development (APD) is a growing subfield of American Politics with important links to other fields of political science, such as political theory, comparative politics, and public law, as well as political sociology and history. Most, but not all, APD work falls within the broad category of historical institutionalism. Its substantive inquiries range widely, but all leading work seeks to conceptualize processes and dynamics of change as they unfold over time, to identify political patterns over the long durée, and to theorize about relations of continuity and change. This seminar surveys classic and contemporary APD scholarship across a range of topics.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will have surveyed classic and contemporary works in the field and will understand key theoretical debates and major methodological approaches.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion (40%), online comments (20%), final exam or research paper (40%)
